newsitem.title: INDIA: India needs higher foreign inflows in 96/97 - RBI.
newsitem.headline: India needs higher foreign inflows in 96/97 - RBI.

text.p: Reserve Bank of India Governor Chakravarty Rangarajan said on Thursday foreign direct and portfolio investments in India should total around $7.5 billion in 1996/97 (April-March).
"There are indications already that inflows in the current year are running at levels higher than in the previous year," Rangarajan said in an address to industrialists in New Delhi.
He said porfolio investments by foreign investors on Indian bourses upto the end of July had reached $1.5 billion.
"The total amount of inflows against GDRs raised upto July 1996 is almost equal to what was received in the full year in 1995/96," Rangarajan added.
He said foreign direct investment upto the end of June totalled $531 million.

"There is a great deal of congruence between foreign investment flows and what the Indian economy requires. We should fashion our policy in such a way that this congruence is maintained and the quantum of foreign investment flows reach the desired level," Rangarajan said.
